pullRequest.body:
We define the strict bicategory of based categories. Its objects are categories equipped with a functor to some fixed base-category. The strict bicategory of fibered categories will later be built on top of this one.

Co-authored-by: Paul Lezeau [paul.lezeau@gmail.com](mailto:paul.lezeau@gmail.com)

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

This is a remake of a previous PR of the same name, but some awful git accident happened and I think its just easier to remake the PR. (I by mistake added 400 commits to the PR by rebasing instead of merging with master in some weird way).

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: @joelriou I already incorporated all, except one, of your comments on the previous PR, thanks a lot for them! The suggestion about making `BasedFunctor` have `functor` as a field instead of extending `Functor` I have not changed yet. That is because this change would not let me use the notation `F.obj` for a `F : BasedFunctor`, and instead I would have to use `F.functor.obj`. Is there a way around this?

> @joelriou I already incorporated all, except one, of your comments on the previous PR, thanks a lot for them! The suggestion about making `BasedFunctor` have `functor` as a field instead of extending `Functor` I have not changed yet. That is because this change would not let me use the notation `F.obj` for a `F : BasedFunctor`, and instead I would have to use `F.functor.obj`. Is there a way around this?

Ok, let us keep `extends`.

### PR summary [4398168f81](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13545/commits/4398168f8131d8e8972c9f5cc331c638d4278453)

#### Import changes

No significant changes to the import graph

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ BasedCategory`
`+ BasedCategory.ofFunctor`
`+ BasedFunctor`
`+ BasedNatTrans`
`+ app_isHomLift`
`+ bicategory`
`+ comp_assoc`
`+ comp_id`
`+ ext`
`+ forgetful`
`+ homCategory`
`+ homCategory.ext`
`+ id_comp`
`+ instance (F : ùí≥ ‚•§·µá ùí¥) (a : ùí≥.obj) : IsHomLift ùí¥.p (ùüô (ùí≥.p.obj a)) (ùüô (F.obj a))`
`+ instance (ùí≥ : BasedCategory.{v‚ÇÇ, u‚ÇÇ} ùíÆ) : Category ùí≥.obj := ùí≥.category`
`+ instance : (forgetful ùí≥ ùí¥).ReflectsIsomorphisms`
`+ instance : Bicategory.Strict (BasedCategory.{v‚ÇÇ, u‚ÇÇ} ùíÆ)`
`+ instance : Category (BasedCategory.{v‚ÇÇ, u‚ÇÇ} ùíÆ)`
`+ instance {F G : ùí≥ ‚•§·µá ùí¥} (Œ± : F ‚ü∂ G) [IsIso Œ±] : IsIso (X:=F.toFunctor) Œ±.toNatTrans := by`
`+ isHomLift`
`+ isHomLift_iff`
`+ isHomLift_map`
`+ isIso_of_toNatTrans_isIso`
`+ mkNatIso`
`+ preserves_isHomLift`
`+ w_obj`
`+ whiskerLeft`
`+ whiskerRight`
`++ comp`
`+++ id`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9634615496/job/26570460480)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9634615496/job/26570460652)

I think we should allow `ùí≥` and `ùí¥` to have different universe parameters. Then, the type of based functors should be equipped with a category structure in this generality. Basically, the data involved in the definitions of the 2-category structure should be more universe polymorphic: the more restricted universe assumption should appear only in the definition of the `Bicategory` instance.
Good point!

```suggestion
instance preserves_isHomLift [IsHomLift ùí≥.p f œÜ] : IsHomLift ùí¥.p f (F.map œÜ) := by
```

```suggestion
lemma isHomLift_map [IsHomLift ùí¥.p f (F.map œÜ)] : IsHomLift ùí≥.p f œÜ := by
```

```suggestion
lemma isHomLift_iff : IsHomLift ùí¥.p f (F.map œÜ) ‚Üî IsHomLift ùí≥.p f œÜ :=
```
A better name should be found.

```suggestion
    ùí≥.obj ‚•§ ùí¥.obj where
```

I believe it is better to generate a single simp lemma `toFunctor` rather than the projections `obj` and `map`:
```suggestion
@[simps toFunctor]
```
Same for `comp` below.
(Note: with the syntax `simps?`, you may see what are the lemmas that are generated.)

```suggestion

initialize_simps_projections BasedNatTrans (+toNatTrans, -app)

/-- The identity natural transformation is a `BasedNatTrans`. -/
@[simps]
def id (F : ùí≥ ‚•§·µá ùí¥) : BasedNatTrans F F where
```
And similarly, `simps!` has to be replaced by `simps` for `comp`. I am not a `simps` tactic guru, but what my suggestion does is that the `simps` attribute on definitions of `BasedNatTrans` will generate the `_toNatTrans` lemmas instead of the `_app` (which may be obtained using `simps!` if this were what we actually wanted).

Then, if `homCategory` is also tagged with `simps` instead of `simps!`, the two lemmas `id/comp_toNatTrans` that you added manually become unnecessary.

(You may try to make the same strategy work for `BasedFunctor`.)
You missed the `initialize_simps_projections` part.
Ah yes I did! So what is actually the point of this? I see that it allows me to write `@[simps]` on `id` instead of `@[simps toNatTrans]`, is that the main benefit?
Yes. For all future declarations of based functors/nat. trans, `@[simps]` will work out of the box.
Instead, could you prove that a based nat. trans is iso if the underlying nat. trans is? Then, `mkNatIsIso` would become basically unnecessary as it would essentially become a special of `asIso`.

That's what I wanted to do originally, but I couldnt seem to get it to work. Both `[IsIso Œ±.toNatTrans]` and `[IsIso (Œ±.toNatTrans : F.toFunctor ‚ü∂ G.toFunctor)]` give type errors (because `Œ±.toNatTrans` is not recognized as a morphism in some category for some reason)
Okay I figured out a trick :)

I think it you be better to make it a lemma rather than an instance. (One approach would be to define a forget functor from based functors to functors, and phrase this by saying this functor reflects isomorphisms.)
Why should it not be an instance? Will type-class inference not work? I will try to implement the approach with the forgetful functor now.
I've left it there for now, but I'm happy to remove it if you think it's not useful.

The "natural" direction is that if a based nat. trans is an iso, then the induced nat. trans is an iso: in this direction, this could certainly an instance. But, having instances in the other direction is problematic because of loops.
Ohhhh I see! Thanks a lot! Then I will add an instance for the other direction instead

```suggestion
lemma isIso_of_toNatTrans_isIso (Œ± : F ‚ü∂ G) [IsIso (X := F.toFunctor) Œ±.toNatTrans] : IsIso Œ± :=
```

In principle, this should no longer be necessary:
```suggestion
@[simps]
```

```suggestion
@[simps]
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(FiberedCategory/BasedCategory): add bicategory of based categories
